text.b: Notice of Finding of No Significant Impact
and Notice of Intent to Request Release of Funds

page.text: Department of Economic Development
1249 W. Main Street
El Centro, CA 92243
This Notice shall satisfy the above-cited two separate but related procedural notification
requirements for activities to be undertaken by the City of El Centro for the Adam Avenue Indoor
Sports Complex.
REQUEST FOR RELEASE OF FUNDS
On or about June 18, 2009, the City of El Centro Department of Economic Development will
submit a request to the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) for the release
CDBG funds under Title 1 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, as
amended, to undertake the redevelopment/replacement of an existing aquatic facility with a
22,000 square foot multi-purpose indoor field complex known as the Adams Avenue Indoor
Sports Complex. The project site is located at the southeast corner of S. 8
th
Street and Adams
Avenue in the City of El Centro, Imperial County, California.
FINDING OF NO SIGNIFICANT IMPACT
The City has determined that the project will have no significant impact on the human
environment. Therefore, an Environmental Impact Statement under the National Environmental
Policy Act (NEPA) of 1969 is not required. Additional project information is contained in the
Environmental Review Record (EER) on file at the City of El Centro Planning & Zoning
Department, 1275 W. Main Street, and may be examined or copied Monday through Friday,
PUBLIC COMMENTS
Any individual, group, or agency disagreeing with this determination or wishing to comment on
the project may submit written comments to Ms. Norma M. Villicaña, Director of Planning &
Zoning. All comments received by June 1, 2009 will be considered by the City prior to
authorizing submission of a request for release of funds. Commentors should specify which
part of this Notice they are addressing.
RELEASE OF FUNDS
The City certifies to HUD that Mr. Ruben A. Duran in his capacity as Certifying Officer consents
to accept the jurisdiction of the Federal Courts if an action is brought to enforce responsibilities
in relation to the environmental review process and that these responsibilities have been
satisfied. HUD’s approval of the certification satisfies its responsibilities under NEPA and
related laws and authorities, and allows the City of El Centro to use Program funds.
OBJECTIONS TO RELEASE OF FUNDS
HUD will accept objections to its release of funds and the City’s certification for a period of
fifteen days following the anticipated submission date or its actual receipt of the request
(whichever is later) only if it is on one of the following bases: (a) the certification was not
executed by the Certifying Officer of the Responsible Entity (RE); (b) the RE has omitted a step
or failed to make a decision or finding required by HUD regulations at 24 CFR Part 58; (c) the
grant recipient or other participants in the project have committed funds or incurred costs not
authorized by 24 CFR Part 58 before approval of a release of funds by HUD; or (d) another
Federal agency acting pursuant to 40 CFR Part 1504 has submitted a written finding that the
project is unsatisfactory from the standpoint of environmental quality. Objections must be
prepared and submitted in accordance with the required procedures (24 CFR Part 58) and shall
be addressed to Office of Community Planning and Development, HUD Region IX, 450 Golden
Gate Avenue, Box 36003, San Francisco, CA 94102-3448. Potential objectors should contact
HUD to verify the actual last day of the objection period.
Mr. Ruben A. Duran
NEPA Certifying Officer
City of El Centro

text.b: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban

San Francisco, California 94107-1387

Project Identification:
Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Southeast Corner of 8th Street and Adams Avenue
El Centro, CA, 92243
Preparer:
Michael Brandman Associates
340 South Farrell Drive
Suite
Palm Springs, CA 92262
Responsible Entity:
City of El Centro Department of Economic Development
Month/Year: May
City of El Centro Department of Economic Development
Ruben Duran, City Manager
Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Southeast corner of 8
th
Street and Adams Avenue, El Centro, CA 92243
1275 West Main Street El Centro
Stacy R. Cox, Community Development Specialist
Conditions for Approval: (List all mitigation measures adopted by the responsible entity to
eliminate or minimize adverse environmental impacts. These conditions must be included in
project contracts and other relevant documents as requirements).
The following Conditions of Approval are applicable to the Adams Avenue Indoor Sports
Complex:
1. The project shall be developed to comply with the commercial zone design standards
as outlined in Section 29-63 of the City Code. Prior to development, the applicant
shall provide architectural elevation, exterior building colors and materials to the City
for review and approval. Building materials and colors shall be chosen to work
harmoniously with adjacent property materials and colors. Building façade materials
and colors shall consist of stucco construction and earth tones or soft muted colors.
2. The project shall provide the required off-street parking spaces for the project site.
Each of the proposed parking stalls shall be a minimum of 9’ x 20’ in size with a 24’
wide paved driveway aisle. All driveway aisles and vehicular access ways shall be
improved and maintained to City standards. In addition, the appropriate number of
accessible parking stalls shall be provided pursuant to ADA requirements. A
minimum five (5’) foot wide walkway shall be maintained between the accessible
parking stalls and the building structure. A maximum of 20% of the required parking
spaces (exclusive of accessible parking stalls) may be designed as compact spaces
(8½’x 17’). All parking areas shall be maintained in accordance with Section 29-134
of the City Code.
3. The project shall provide a minimum of one (1) 12’ x 40’ loading space in accordance
with City standards.
4. Vehicular access ways on the same lot, building site or project shall be not less than
sixty (60) feet apart as measured along the street frontage.
5. Driveway approaches proposed on properties in commercial areas are limited to a
maximum width of thirty-two (32’) feet, unless approval for a larger width is obtained by
the Department of Public Works.
6. An outside refuse collection area shall be provided for each building. The outside
refuse collection area shall be screened by a six (6’) foot high decorative stucco wall
with concrete floor and apron and chain link gate with privacy slats. In addition, a
minimum six (6”) inch thick concrete pad shall be provided in front of the trash
enclosure in accordance with the City’s standards. Colors and materials of said
trash enclosure shall match the façade of the proposed building. Contact the
sanitation company (CR&R) for further information on the size and number of the
refuse/recycling container(s) required for the proposed project at (760) 482-5655.
7. The project shall provide any required street dedications and/or off-site
improvements (curb, gutter, sidewalk, paving, street lighting, ADA accessibility) to
City standards along North 8
th
Street, Pico Avenue and North 7
th
Street.
Encroachment permits and approval from the City shall be obtained for any
driveways and/or required off-site improvements along North 8
th
Street, Pico Avenue
and North 7
th
Street.
8. Any substandard sidewalk segments along Adams Avenue shall be replaced.
Encroachment permits and approval from Caltrans shall be obtained for all driveways
and/or any required offsite improvements along Adams Avenue (Highway 86).
9. The project shall provide and maintain a minimum of 15% of the site with
landscaping. All landscaping shall be provided in accordance with Section 29-142 of
the City Code and shall consist primarily of live vegetation. A minimum of eighty
(80%) percent of the required landscaping shall be provided within the frontage area
or areas visible from a public street. Trees shall be located throughout the parking
lot in curbed and irrigated planters and not simply at the ends of the parking aisles.
A minimum of one tree per 200 square feet of landscaping or one tree for every fifth
parking stall, whichever is more, shall be provided. A top dressing shall be provided
in all planter areas. Gravel or decorative rocks within the project site shall not be
used in lieu of vegetative ground cover. Landscaping and irrigation plans prepared
by a licensed landscape architect shall be submitted to the City for approval prior to
the issuance of building permits. Such landscaping shall include trees of a size and
type in compliance with the other provisions of the landscaping ordinance and
planted twenty (20) feet on center or equivalent approved spacing.
10. All undeveloped areas within the building site shall be covered with blacktop,
concrete, recycled asphalt, landscaping or an approved dust preventive ground
covering.
11. A drainage plan shall be submitted to the City for review and approval prior to the
issuance of building permits. Said drainage plan shall describe the method for
handling drainage of the site.
12. The project shall provide lighting within the parking lot to City standards. All outdoor
lighting within the parking lot shall be hooded and arranged to deflect away from
adjacent properties and City streets.
13. The project shall comply with all applicable provisions of the California Code of
Regulations Title 24 (ADA).
14. Project construction operations must adhere to the measures found in the Imperial
County Air Pollution Control District (ICAPCD) Regulation-Fugitive Dust Rules as
well as ICAPCD CEQA Handbook Measure for Construction equipment and fugitive
PM10 control that assist in reducing short-term air pollutant emission (ICAPCD
2006). The ICAPCD Rules and Regulations can be found at
http://www.imperialcounty.net.
15. Building permits shall not be issued for any new construction related to the project
until verification from the elementary and high school districts is received, certifying
that the State mandated school impact mitigation fees have been paid or addressed
as otherwise provided or authorized by law.
16. Building permits shall not be issued for any new construction related to the project
until the appropriate development impact and sewer/water capacity fees have been
paid to the City.
17. The project shall be developed in accordance with the Fire Department’s fire
protection features and specified fire lane designations.
18. The project site shall be maintained in a good, clean, orderly manner, free of any
debris or junk materials.
19. Pursuant to Section 29-343(a) of the City Code, this Site Plan Review shall become
null and void if not exercised within one (1) year.
20. The project shall comply with all other applicable State and City regulations,
ordinances and resolutions.
In addition, the following mitigation measures also apply during construction or operation of the
Adams Indoor Sports Park:
Any modification to project’s existing Lighting Plan shall require a photometric
analysis prior to building final. External lighting modifications, if proposed, shall
be energy-efficient and shielded, filtered, or recessed so that direct glare and
reflections are contained within the boundaries of the project, and shall be
directed downward and away from adjoining properties and from public right-of-
ways or open space areas.
Prior to commencement of construction activities, including demolition and
grading, the construction contractor shall prepare a Dust Control Plan (DCP) to
be implemented during all construction activities per ICAPCD Rule 801 Section
F.2, subject to review and approval by the City Engineer and ICAPCD.
The construction contractor shall comply with ICAPCD Rule 801, Construction
and Earthmoving Activities, sections E, F and G to the satisfaction of the Public
Works Director and ICAPCD.
Prior to the issuance of a building permit, to the extent feasible, the City shall
demonstrate that the design of the proposed buildings or structures exceed by 5
percent 2008 Building Energy Efficiency Standards for Residential and
Nonresidential Buildings. In addition, the project shall use roof material with a
solar reflectance value meeting the EPA/DOE Energy Star® rating to reduce
summer cooling needs. The project shall also use energy efficient lighting where
new lighting is to be installed. Documentation of compliance with this measure
shall be provided to the City of El Centro Building Official for review and approval
prior to issuance of building permit(s) and approval of features shall be confirmed
by the City of El Centro Building Official prior to certificate of occupancy.
The design of the facility shall include landscaping such as shade trees around
main buildings and around the parking lots. The trees, shrubs, and groundcover
shall be drought tolerant. The landscaping shall consist of drought-resistant
plants in lieu of turf, wherever feasible.
The design of the facility shall include a recycling component for storage of
recyclables and green waste. The project shall also include recycling receptacle
for each building strategically placed to facilitate recycling used beverage
containers. This measure is designed to capture single use beverage containers
(i.e., personal water bottles) and not large deposits (i.e., household recycling).
These receptacles shall be placed in visible locations and shall be well marked
with recycle signs.
During demolition and construction, the construction contractor shall reduce
and/or salvage at least 50 percent of non-hazardous construction debris. A
construction waste reduction plan shall be submitted to the City Building Official
prior to issuance of building permits.
To reduce water consumption inside the buildings during occupancy, the
following measures shall be confirmed by the City County Building Official prior to
issuance of a certificate of occupancy. All bathroom sink faucets and toilets shall
be water efficient (i.e., use the U.S. EPA WaterSense label), except where
prohibited by the Americans with Disabilities Act.
If subsurface resources are discovered during construction, operations shall stop
in the immediate vicinity of the find and the qualified archaeologist shall be
consulted to determine whether the resource requires further study. The
qualified archeologist shall make recommendations to the City on the measures
that shall be implemented to protect the discovered resources, including but not
limited to excavation of the finds and evaluation of the finds in accordance with
California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Section 15064.5.
The project shall comply with Section 17.1 of the Noise Ordinance with regard to
interior and exterior noise generated from the proposed indoor sports complex.
Methods of acoustical screening shall be incorporated into HVAC equipment for
proposed indoor sports complex.
A traffic monitoring program shall be drafted to outline plans for directing traffic
and pedestrians to and from the indoor sports complex in a timely manner during
special events.
Control of Construction Hours – All construction activities shall comply with
Section 17.1-8 of the City’s Noise Ordinance.
To accommodate the project site’s maximum attendance potential, Phase III
proposed parking shall be completed prior to scheduling of special events at the
Indoor Sports Complex.
The City shall conduct a parking analysis in confirming which uses are and are
not allowable for sustainable parking for the Indoor Sports Complex. The
analysis shall set forth conditions regulating types of events to occur at the
Indoor Sports Complex.
(The project will not result in a significant impact on the quality of the human
environment)
___ Finding of Significant Impact
(The project may significantly affect the quality of the human environment)
Nancy M. Ferguson, Regional Manager, Michael Brandman Associates
Name/Title/Agency:__
Ruben Duran, City Manager, City of El Centro Economic
Development Department

text.b: Statement of Purpose and Need for the Proposal:

page.text: The proposed 22,000 square foot Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex would provide youths
with an indoor, “climatic-suitable” environment for athletic activities away from adverse weather
related conditions (i.e., extreme heat) commonly experienced during the summer season. The
project involves the construction of a multi-purpose indoor field complex solely for the purpose
of seasoned athletic events and sports-related activities for public utilization.
The proposed project is for the redevelopment/replacement of the aquatic recreational facility
with a 22,000 square foot multi-purpose indoor, field complex. Initial phase of redevelopment
will commence with the demolition of two existing swimming pools, bathroom/shower facilities,
shaded bleachers, and a large façade facing North 8
th
Street. Once demolition is completed,
the indoor sports complex will be constructed (Phase I) to include a multi-sport field court with
bleachers all enclosed within a 200-foot by 110-foot structural membrane. Latter phase (Phase
III) development will include the construction of additional onsite parking to accommodate public
utilization of the Indoor Sports Park. The playing field will be artificial turf rather than sod.
The project site is a 2.35-acre parcel of developed land identified as APN 053-031-004. The
parcel is zoned LU, limited use. The location is urban, and surrounded on all sides by
development. To the north is the Premier Inn, northeast is high density residential housing, east
is a public park, southeast is conventional single unit housing, south and west are commercial
businesses, including a 7/11 convenience store. With the projected increase in local population,
the City of El Centro has prepared a “Twenty Year Comprehensive Parks and Recreation
Facilities Master Plan.” The plan, which includes the proposed project, focuses on creation of
new park space, upkeep and maintenance to existing facilities and citizen participation into
decisions regarding parks and recreation within the City.
NORT
H
Michael Brandman Associates

NOR
TH
Feet
A Historic Resources Assessment was prepared for the
proposed project that is attached to this EA (Appendix B).
Based on the results of the records search, the existing land-
use, and development within and adjacent to the project area,
and the parameters of the proposed construction, the potential
for impacts to any buried and potentially significant cultural and
paleontological resources is considered low. Existing
resources have been evaluated at the CEQA- and Section
106-level of analysis and are not considered significant at the
National, State or Local levels of analysis. Under these
conditions and following CEQA guidelines, cultural and
paleontological resource monitoring during grading and
construction is not recommended.
It is always possible that ground-disturbing activities during
construction may uncover previously unknown, buried cultural
resources without a monitor or archaeologist present. In the
event that buried cultural resources are discovered during
construction, operations shall stop in the immediate vicinity of
the find and a qualified archaeologist shall be consulted to
determine whether the resource requires further study. The
qualified archeologist shall make recommendations to the Lead
Agency on the measures that shall be implemented to protect
the discovered resources, including but not limited to
excavation of the finds and evaluation of the finds in
accordance with Section 15064.5 of the CEQA guidelines.
If the resources are determined to be unique historic resources
as defined under Section 15064.5 of the CEQA Guidelines,
mitigation measures shall be identified by the archaeologist
and recommended to the Lead Agency.
In addition, reasonable efforts to avoid, minimize, or mitigate
adverse effects to the property will be taken, and the State
Historic Preservation Office (SHPO) and Native American
tribes with concerns about the property, as well as the Advisory
Council on Historic Preservation (ACHP), will be notified within
48 hours in compliance with 36 CFR 800.13(b)(3).
In the event of an accidental discovery or recognition of any
human remains, PRC Section 5097.98 must be followed. In
this instance, once project-related earthmoving begins and if
there is accidental discovery or recognition of any human
remains in any location other than a dedicated cemetery, steps
would be taken: as outlined in the measures identified in the
Conditions of Approval section.
These measures are all enumerated in the Conditions of
Approval above.
[24 CFR 55, Executive Order 11988]
The project is not located within a 100-year flood hazard as
mapped by FEMA Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM)
Community Panel Number 060670 1725 C, dated September
[Executive Order 11990]
Because there are no wetlands as defined in Section 404 of
the Clean Water Act on or near the proposed project, no
wetlands would be affected by the project. (Field Observation)
[Sections 307(c),(d)]
The project site is located inland and is far from any large
coastal water bodies. Therefore, the Coastal Zone
Management Act not applicable to the project site.
The City of El Centro does not utilize its groundwater supply for
consumption, due to the groundwater being too brackish in
quality for human consumption and agricultural uses. Instead,
the project would continue to utilize the City’s water rather than
groundwater, which would not result in a net deficit of aquifer
volume or lowering of the groundwater table. Therefore, the
issue of a Sole Source Aquifer does not apply to this project.
Because the project site is already developed, the chance of
encountering a sensitive species onsite is minimal. There are
some sensitive wildlife species, sensitive plant species, and
sensitive plant communities described by the California Natural
Diversity Data Base (CNDDB) as having potential to occur in
the project vicinity. However, the potential to find such species
in or around the project site is very low due to the lack of
natural vegetation on-site, the heavy disturbance of the natural
environment, the urban nature of the site and vicinity, and the
lack of undisturbed habitat in the project vicinity. Therefore, no
project specific habitat assessment, focused surveys or
biological monitoring will be necessary for the proposed
project. There will be no impact to biological resources as a
result of the proposed project (Field Observation).
[Sections 7 (b), (c)]
The project site does not drain into a stream or river and will
not alter existing drainage patterns since the project site has
already been developed. (Field Observation).
[Clean Air Act, Sections 176 (c)
and (d), and 40 CFR 6, 51, 93]
Redevelopment of the 2.35-acre project site will not impact air
quality. The proposed project is in an attainment area or
conforms to the EPA-approved State Implementation Plan
(SIP) for all components. The project includes mitigation
measures and project design features to increase bicycle use
and to reduce vehicle miles traveled. The project will also
comply with all existing rules and regulations pertaining to the
project, including Regulation VII, which has a purpose to
reduce fugitive dust during construction. For these reasons,
the project is consistent with the Air Quality Attainment Plan
(AQAP).
Mitigation measures identified the in Conditions of Approval
listed above would be implemented during construction and/or
operation of the facility.
There is no Prime Farmland, Unique Farmland, or Farmland of
Statewide Importance on or adjacent to the proposed project.
(Field Observation, City of El Centro General Plan).
[Executive Order 12898]
The site is designated in the General Plan and Zoning maps
for Limited Use, and that no adverse environmental conditions
affect the site.
The project will provide recreational opportunities to serve the
local residents. It would not expose low income or minority
populations to adverse environmental conditions. The project
is the replacement of a swimming complex with playing fields
and other amenities that can be used by local residents year-
round.
(City of El Centro General Plan; California Environmental
Protection Agency, Cortese List Data Resources. 2009.
Website: www.calepa.ca.gov/SiteCleanup/CorteseList/.
[24 CFR 51 B]
Although most on-site recreational activities hosted within the
indoor sports complex are not anticipated to violate the
applicable noise standards, there does remain the possibility
that noise levels could exceed 65 dB(A) from within and
outside of the sports complex during special events (i.e,
soccer games, auctions, concerts). This could subject
residents along the south side of Park Avenue to the
possibility of “nuisance noise.” It is therefore recommended
that mitigation require the project development’s adherence to
Section 17.1 of the City’s Noise Ordinance. See Conditions of
Approval above.
The project site is not located on or near to a site listed as a
hazardous materials site pursuant to Government Code
Section 65962.5. There are no above- or below-ground
storage tanks (AST, UST), soil stains, or other types of
potential hazards to the public. (California Environmental
Protection Agency, Cortese List Data Resources. 2009.
Website: www.calepa.ca.gov/SiteCleanup/CorteseList/.
[24 CFR 51 C]
The project site will not expose either people or buildings to
additional hazards. The project site is fully surrounded by
residential and commercial uses that do not involve the above
ground storage of explosive or flammable materials.
(California Environmental Protection Agency, Cortese List
Data Resources. 2009. Website:
www.calepa.ca.gov/SiteCleanup/CorteseList/
[24 CFR 51 D]
The project site is not located within an airport land use
designated area, nor is it located within 2 miles of a private
airport. The project site is also not located within and
Accident Potential Zone (City of El Centro General Plan).
[Environmental Review Guide HUD CPD 782, 24 CFR 58.40; Ref. 40 CFR 1508.8 &1508.27]
Evaluate the significance of the effects of the proposal on the character, features and resources
of the project area. Enter relevant base data and verifiable source documentation to support the
finding. Then enter the appropriate impact code from the following list to make a determination
of impact. Impact Codes: (1) - No impact anticipated; (2) - Potentially beneficial; (3) -
Potentially adverse; (4) - Requires mitigation; (5) - Requires project modification. Note names,
dates of contact, telephone numbers and page references. Attach additional material as
appropriate. Note conditions or mitigation measures required.
The proposed use (indoor athletic sports park) would
provide a public service that is essential to City of El
Centro’s, Public Facilities: Goal 1 of the General Plan
in providing for adequate year-round recreational
activities and facilities that serve all segments of the
community (City of El Centro General Plan).
The proposed use (indoor athletic sports park) is an
infill, redevelopment project that is compatible and
supportive of surrounding residential uses and
replaces an existing recreational use. (Field
Observation)
Due to the project area being completely flat with no
slope, there is no potential for a landslide to occur,
thereby posing no impact to the project site (Field
Observation).
The proposed project would require the
implementation of a drainage plan that complies with
requirements of the State Water Resources Control
Board General Construction Permit which would
control the potential for erosion from storm water
runoff to occur (see Condition of Approval No. 11). In
addition, the contractors must also comply with
Imperial County Air Pollution Control District
requirements for control of fugitive dust during
construction which would control wind erosion. (see
Condition of Approval No. 14) Also see measures AQ-
1 and AQ-2.
See Condition of Approval No. 10 to control the
potential for erosion to occur during long-term
operation of the facilities.
In general, much of the near surface soils in the
Imperial Valley consist of silty clays and clays, which
are moderate to highly expansive. The native surface
clays exhibit moderate to high expansion potential and
the clay is expansive when wetted and can shrink with
moisture loss (drying). When the site was originally
developed for the Plunge, the owner raised the site by
4 feet to prevent storm water from entering the site.
When the site is redeveloped as part of the proposed
project the area will be graded to lower it by 4 feet to
be level with the surrounding area. During grading,
soils will be engineered to provide the necessary
compaction to support the foundations of the habitable
structures. Likewise, as necessary, the soils where
future parking lots are proposed would be engineered
as necessary to prevent pavement cracking, etc.
The project does not propose a land use that would
have the potential for the release of hazardous
materials into the environment. The project site is not
located on or near to a site listed as a hazardous
materials site pursuant to Government Code Section
65962.5. There are no above- or below-ground
storage tanks (AST, UST), soil stains, or other types of
potential hazards to the public.
The project site is not located within an airport land
use designated area, nor is it located within 2 miles of
a private airport. The project site is also not located
within an Accident Potential Zone.
(City of El Centro General Plan; California
Environmental Protection Agency, Cortese List Data
Resources. 2009. Website:
www.calepa.ca.gov/SiteCleanup/CorteseList/.
The project site is located in the City of El Centro, in
an area with hot dry summers and cool mild winters.
The City is proposing that the park be an indoor park
that can be used year-round to accommodate local
residents’ recreational activities. The indoor park
would be temperature controlled with state-of-the-art
equipment designed to be energy efficient. (see
Mitigation Measure AQ-3 above)
Although most on-site recreational activities hosted
within the indoor sports park are not anticipated to
violate the applicable noise standards, there does
remain the possibility that noise levels could exceed
65 dB(A) from within and outside of the interior during
special events (i.e. soccer games, auctions, concerts).
This could expose residents along the south side of
Park Avenue to short term increases in noise. (see
Mitigation Measure NOI-1 for the project’s adherence
to Section 17.1 of the City’s Noise Ordinance)
It is also unknown what type of heating, ventilating and
air conditioning units (HVAC) are being proposed, how
units will be acoustically screened and where units will
be located for the indoor sports complex. This can
create a significant noise impact especially if proposed
HVAC units have an operational sound level of 80.5
Db(A) or more, or if multiple HVAC units are proposed.
(See Mitigation Measure NOI-2)
Furthermore, traffic noise levels along Park Avenue
during future park-held events could temporarily
exceed the 70-CNEL standard for the site’s zoning
designation (Limited Use). Therefore, mitigation will
be required to address impacts created from traffic-
induced noise. (See Mitigation Measure NOI-3)
Development of the 2.35-acre project site will not
adversely impact air quality. The proposed project is
in an attainment area or conforms to the EPA-
approved State Implementation Plan (SIP) for all
components. The project includes mitigation
measures and project design features to increase
bicycle use and to reduce vehicle miles traveled. The
project will also comply with all existing rules and
regulations pertaining to the project, including
Regulation VII, which has a purpose to reduce fugitive
dust during construction. For these reasons, the
project is consistent with the Air Quality Attainment
Plan (AQAP). (See mitigation measures AQ-1 and
AQ-2)
Scenic vistas in the region are typically thought of as
landscape views of open space and distant mountains.
There are no scenic vistas in the project area since the
downtown area’s, main focus is predominately on
architectural and cultural themes. State Highway 86
(Adams Avenue) which runs east to west along the
north side of the project site, is not registered, nor is
eligible for State Scenic Highway status.
The project has the potential to emit ambient amounts
of light onto adjacent multifamily residential dwellings
located south of the project site. The City proposes to
install overhead lighting for the indoor field and to
utilize external wall mounted lighting from the existing
gymnasium. Existing pole-mounted lighting bordering
the tennis courts will also be utilized for the project’s
proposed east-end parking lot. Any modification to
existing external lighting involving the increase of
ambient light sources to the project site shall require a
photometric analysis and to require containment of
light source emissions within the boundaries of the
project site. (See Mitigation Measure AES-1)
The project site will not introduce any barriers, which
would isolate a particular neighborhood or population
group, nor will it destroy or harm any community
institution. The proposed project is for the
redevelopment replacement of the aquatic recreational
facility with a 22,000 square foot multi-purpose indoor,
field complex.
There are no existing residential dwelling units within
the project. The proposed project is for the
redevelopment replacement of the aquatic recreational
facility with a 22,000 square foot multi-purpose indoor,
field complex. No people would be displaced as a
result.
Although the project site will create temporary
construction jobs, the project will not disrupt
employment and income patterns of the City. The
project will serve only for the purpose of providing
recreational activities for the City’s adults and youth
population.
The project does not include plans for residential
development therefore a need for more schools has
not been generated. However, as identified in
Condition of Approval No. 15, the City must pay the
state-mandated fees for schools.
The project does not include plans for residential
development necessitating the need for commercial
facilities. The project site is a adjacent to
commercially designated zoning along Adams Avenue
with a convenience store (7-Eleven) directly west of
the project site. (Field Observation)
The nearest medical services to serve the project site
would be provided by El Centro Regional Medical
Center, which is located 1.15 mile southwest of the
project site at 1415 Ross Avenue, El Centro, CA.
The nearest social services to serve the project site
would be provided by Imperial County Department of
Social Services, located 1.02 mile southeast of the
project site at 1095 South 4
th
Street, El Centro, CA.
The project would comply with all applicable federal,
state, and local statutes and regulations pertaining to
solid waste The nearest solid waste landfill to serve
the project site would be provided by the Allied
Imperial Landfill, which is located 4.60 miles northeast
of the project site at 104 East Robinson Road in an
unincorporated portion of Imperial County. The landfill
currently has a capacity sufficient for the next 14
years. Mitigation Measure AQ-6 requires a
construction waste plan be developed that shows that
during demolition and construction the contractor shall
reduce or salvage at least 50 % of the non-hazardous
construction debris.
The City of El Centro already provides water and
wastewater services to the project site through
connections along Adams Avenue The proposed
project’s wastewater treatment demands can be met
through existing City service providers thereby
preventing and exceedance of treatment requirements.
Although the project is not located within a 100-year
flood hazard as mapped by a Flood Insurance Rate
Map (FEMA), the project site would be required to
submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) to the RWQCB that
covers the General Construction Permit (GCP) prior to
the beginning of construction. The contractor will be
required to prepare and implement a drainage plan
that meets the intent of the RWQCB requirements for a
Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan (see Condition
of Approval No. 11)
The City of El Centro does not utilize its groundwater
supply for consumption, due to the groundwater being
too brackish in quality for human consumption and
agricultural uses. Instead, the project would continue
to utilize the City’s water rather than groundwater,
which would not result in a net deficit of aquifer volume
or lowering of the groundwater table.
The project is the replacement of the City’s public
aquatic facilities consisting of two swimming pools and
related uses (showers, dressing rooms etc.) with a
new indoor sports complex including a playing field
using artificial turf rather than sod, and related uses
(showers, dressing rooms etc.). No increase in the
amount of water is anticipated since the playing fields
will be made of artificial turf.
The project site will be adequately served by police
protection services. Most activities (i.e., soccer match)
would involve non-discretionary review by the City.
Larger attendance events (i.e. concert) would be
subject to the City’s Special Event Permit (SEP) for
discretionary review to ensure compliance with the
Police Department’s regulation criteria for Special
Events.
The project site will be adequately served by fire
protection services. Most activities (i.e., soccer match)
would involve non-discretionary review by the City.
Larger attendance events (i.e. concert) would be
subject to the City’s Special Event Permit (SEP) for
discretionary review to ensure compliance with the Fire
Department’s regulation criteria for special events.
Nearest medical services to serve the project site
would be provided by El Centro Regional Medical
Center, which is located 1.15 mile southwest of the
project site at 1415 Ross Avenue, El Centro, CA.
The project would not require the need for additional
open space since the project is proposed for
redevelopment to an existing developed recreation
area.
The project site is for the proposed redevelopment to
an existing recreational facility and does not require
expansion to existing facilities. The proposed project
would replace the existing aquatic facility with the
proposed Indoor Sports Complex. At a future date, the
City intends to replace the aquatic facilities with similar
facilities on the park site east of 7
th
Street.
The project site has a highly disturbed surface and
contains no known archeological resources. However
it is always possible that cultural resources could be
detected during ground disturbing activities. Shallow
grading and excavation of the surface and subsurface
is proposed. Relocation of existing utilities
underground would also require excavations below
finished grade. If in the event that an accidental
discovery is made, reasonable efforts to avoid,
minimize, or mitigate adverse effects to the property
will be undertaken immediately as a matter of law, and
notification of the appropriate authorities will be made
within 48 hours, in compliance with 36 CFR
800.13(b)(3). (see Mitigation Measure CR-1)
A Traffic Impact Analysis was prepared by KOA
Corporation (Appendix D) in addressing potential
impacts to traffic circulation from project development.
The analysis found that the project would not require
street closures during construction, and concluded that
existing roadway segments adjacent to the project
would continue to operate at the same level of service
(LOS) as prior to project development.
The proposed parking lots would need to be completed
to accommodate events at the indoor sports park.
This would require Phase III construction of the
proposed parking lot along 7
th
Street to be completed
prior to scheduled sports events.
In addition, the City’s Planning Department would need
to confirm that proposed parking would sufficiently
accommodate such uses including other uses that may
otherwise require additional parking. Therefore,
impacts from inadequate parking capacity would be
less than significant.
(KOA Corporation. 2009. Adams Avenue Sports
Complex Traffic Impact Study. City of El Centro,
California.)
There are no water resources associated with the
project site or vicinity. The site and surrounding area
is urban and there are no streams or other water
resources located in the vicinity. City of El Centro
does not utilize its groundwater supply for
consumption, due to the groundwater being too
brackish in quality for human consumption and
agricultural uses. Instead, the project would continue
to utilize the City’s water rather than groundwater,
which would not result in a net deficit of aquifer volume
or lowering of the groundwater table.
Based on map analysis and field reconnaissance there
are no federal or state jurisdictional waters located
within the project area or adjacent to the project site.
The project site is fully developed and does not
contain Unique Natural Features of significant value in
warranting preservation.
The project site does not contain Prime Farmland,
Unique Farmland, or Farmland of Statewide
Importance on or adjacent to the project site. The
proposed project area is not zoned for agricultural use
and is not under contract for agricultural land use.
Because the project site is already developed, the
chance of encountering a sensitive species onsite is
minimal. There are some sensitive wildlife species,
sensitive plant species, and sensitive plant
communities described by the California Natural
Diversity Data Base (CNDDB) as having potential to
occur in the project vicinity. However, the potential to
find such species in or around the project area is very
low due to the lack of natural vegetation on-site, the
heavy disturbance of the natural environment, the
presence of domestic animals and pests, and the lack
of undisturbed habitat in the project vicinity.
Therefore, the potential for affecting biological
resources is not significant and no project specific
habitat assessment, focused surveys or biological
monitoring will be necessary for the proposed project.
The project is not located within a 100-year flood
hazard as mapped by FEMA Flood Insurance Rate
Map (FIRM) Community Panel Number 060670 1725
C, dated September 26, 2008.
The project site is located inland and is far from any
large coastal water bodies. Therefore, the Act not
applicable to the project site.
The project site is not located within an airport land
use designated area, nor is it located within 2 miles of
a private airport. The project site is also not located
within and Accident Potential Zone.
(City of El Centro General Plan)
None.
The proposed project with mitigation incorporated will reduce all impacts to environmental
criteria outlined in this Environmental Assessment Document to less than significant. The
proposed use (indoor athletic sports park) would provide a public service that is essential to
Public Facilities Goal 1 of the General Plan in providing for adequate year-round recreational
activities and facilities that serve all segments of the community.
[24 CFR 58.40(e), Ref. 40 CFR
No project alternatives have been proposed at this time.
Without implementation the project site would remain as the City’s existing aquatic center that is
closed and in disrepair, thereby subjecting the site to additional blighted conditions.
Furthermore, without the proposed temperature controlled indoor sports complex, local
residents would be deprived of recreational activities and sports events, or these events would
take place further from the local area. In addition, due to the high temperatures during summer
months, recreational activities would be restricted to evening hours in order to avoid extreme
heat during the summer, or relocate to pre-existing facilities thus presenting overcrowding on
existing recreational resources.
Any modification to project’s existing Lighting Plan shall require a photometric
analysis prior to building final. External lighting modifications, if proposed, shall
be energy-efficient and shielded, filtered, or recessed so that direct glare and
reflections are contained within the boundaries of the project, and shall be
directed downward and away form adjoining properties and from public right-of-
ways or open space areas.
Prior to commencement of construction activities, including demolition and
grading, the construction contractor shall prepare a Dust Control Plan (DCP) to
be implemented during all construction activities per ICAPCD Rule 801 Section
F.2, subject to review and approval by the City Engineer and ICAPCD.
The construction contractor shall comply with ICAPCD Rule 801, Construction
and Earthmoving Activities, sections E, F, and G to the satisfaction of the Public
Works Director and ICAPCD.
Prior to the issuance of a building permit, to the extent feasible, the City shall
demonstrate that the design of the proposed buildings or structures exceed by 5
percent 2008 Building Energy Efficiency Standards for Residential and
Nonresidential Buildings. In addition, the project shall use roof material with a
solar reflectance value meeting the EPA/DOE Energy Star® rating to reduce
summer cooling needs. The project shall also use energy efficient lighting where
new lighting is to be installed. Documentation of compliance with this measure
shall be provided to the City of El Centro Building Official for review and approval
prior to issuance of building permit(s) and approval of features shall be confirmed
by the City of El Centro Building Official prior to certificate of occupancy.
The design of the facility shall include landscaping such as shade trees around
main buildings and around the parking lots. The trees, shrubs, and groundcover
shall be drought tolerant. The landscaping shall consist of drought-resistant
plants in lieu of turf, wherever feasible.
The design of the facility shall include a recycling component for storage of
recyclables and green waste. The project shall also include recycling receptacle
for each building strategically placed to facilitate recycling used beverage
containers. This measure is designed to capture single use beverage containers
(i.e., personal water bottles) and not large deposits (i.e., household recycling).
These receptacles shall be placed in visible locations and shall be well marked
with recycle signs.
During demolition and construction, the construction contractor shall reduce
and/or salvage at least 50 percent of non-hazardous construction debris. A
construction waste reduction plan shall be submitted to the City Building Official
prior to issuance of building permits.
To reduce water consumption inside the buildings during occupancy, the
following measures shall be confirmed by the City County Building Official prior to
issuance of a certificate of occupancy. All bathroom sink faucets and toilets shall
be water efficient (i.e., use the U.S. EPA WaterSense label), except where
prohibited by the Americans with Disabilities Act.
If subsurface resources are discovered during construction, operations shall stop
in the immediate vicinity of the find and the qualified archaeologist shall be
consulted to determine whether the resource requires further study. The
qualified archeologist shall make recommendations to the City on the measures
that shall be implemented to protect the discovered resources, including but not
limited to excavation of the finds and evaluation of the finds in accordance with
California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines Section 15064.5.
The project shall comply with Section 17.1 of the Noise Ordinance with regard to
interior and exterior noise generated from the proposed indoor sports complex.
Methods of acoustical screening shall be incorporated into HVAC equipment for
proposed indoor sports complex.
A traffic monitoring program shall be drafted to outline plans for directing traffic
and pedestrians to and from the indoor sports complex in a timely manner during
special events.
Control of Construction Hours – All construction activities shall comply with
Section 17.1-8 of the City’s Noise Ordinance.
To accommodate the project site’s maximum attendance potential, Phase III
proposed parking shall be completed prior to scheduling of special events at the
Indoor Sports Complex.
The City shall conduct a parking analysis in confirming which uses are and are
not allowable for sustainable parking for the Indoor Sports Complex. Said
analysis shall set forth conditions regulating types of events to occur at the
Indoor Sports Complex.
See attached additional studies

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

Appendix A: Air Quality Background Information and Model Output
Appendix B: Historic Resources Assessment
Appendix C: KOA Traffic Study

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
The City of El Centro, as Lead Agency, has prepared this Initial Study (IS) to evaluate potential
environmental impacts associated with the proposed demolition of the aquatic recreational facilities
and the development of the Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex (“project” or “proposed project”);
and to present strategies that will lessen such impacts. This document satisfies the requirements set
forth in the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), and is the environmental document
prepared pursuant to the provisions of CEQA, Public Resources Code 21000, et. seq. for
consideration in conjunction with the proposed project. City officials and responsible agencies will
use this document as an aid for making sound planning decisions.
The project site is located in the City of El Centro, in the County of Imperial, California
(See Exhibit 1 – Regional Location). Specifically, the project location is on the southeast corner of
Adams Avenue and North 8
th
Street. Its boundaries are Adams Avenue to the north, 7
th
Street to the
east, Park Avenue to the south, and North 8
th
Street to the west (See Exhibit 2 – Project Vicinity).
The project site is a 2.35-acre parcel of developed land identified as (APN) 053-031-004 that is zoned
LU, limited use. The location is urban, and surrounded on all sides by development. To the north is
the Premier Inn, northeast is high density residential housing; east is a public park, southeast is
conventional single-family homes, and southwest are commercial businesses (See Exhibit 3 – Local
Aerial).
According to the City’s Parks and Recreation Master Plan (September 18, 2008) the Adams Avenue
Indoor Sports Complex is the first project recommended for Phase I (within the next 5 years) of the
City’s long-range plan for parks and recreation facilities. The Conrad Harrison Youth Center’ will
remain at its current location. Redevelopment plans are proposed to work around the gymnasium
building. Exhibit 3 and Exhibit 4 show the existing conditions on the project site.
The proposed project includes the replacement of the existing aquatic recreational facility with a
multi-purpose indoor sports field complex (see Exhibit 5, Conceptual Site Plan). The plans include
demolition of two existing swimming pools, bathroom/shower facilities, shaded bleachers, and a large
façade facing North 8
th
Street. The site will be graded to street level (approximately 4 feet maximum
cut) to allow for proper site drainage.
The indoor sports complex includes a multi-sport field, courts and bleachers, all enclosed within a
200-foot by 110-foot structural membrane (22,000 square feet), playing fields artificial turf, and

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
landscaping around the site will be low water using drought-tolerant plants. The project also includes
construction of a one-story structure that will be the main entrance for the existing gymnasium and
the new sports complex. This new structure will include bathroom/shower facilities, an office, a
kitchen/concession stand, and ticket booth and maintenance storage with covered walkways
connecting to the existing gym and the proposed sports complex. Proposed parking will consist of
118 off-street parking stalls located abutting perpendicular to the north side of Park Avenue, along the
south side (existing) of the gymnasium, and east of the existing gym.
The project is proposed to be built in three phases.
Phase I is the installation of the membrane structure, covered walkways and the
construction of the one-story structure. Most cut and fill grading will be completed
during this phase, and 26 parking spaces will be installed along Park Avenue;
Phase II includes the installation of the sports equipment and artificial turf in the
membrane structure; and
Phase III includes the development of the parking lot proposed along North 7
th
Street
and off-street parking along Park Avenue.
In addition to the project description presented above, all zoning ordinances, permit requirements of
responsible agencies, and the mitigation measures included in this environmental document will be
made conditions of approval (COA).
This document satisfies CEQA requirements for environmental evaluation of a proposed project
where a discretionary action is required. In this case, the discretionary action is a Conditional Use
Permit (CUP) for operation of the planned facilities. CEQA requires that any qualifying project on
which a municipality needs to exercise discretionary authority must first prepare an
assessment/evaluation of the environment to determine the potential impacts of the project. This IS
and Notice of Intent (NOI) to Adopt a Mitigated Negative Declaration (MND) are informational
documents intended to inform the City of El Centro decision makers, responsible agencies, and
interested parties of the potential environmental effects of the proposed project and allow them to
provide comments to be considered by the City Council in their review and consideration of the
project.
A field visit and windshield survey was conducted on January 7, 2009 by MBA staff to document
existing conditions on the site and in the general area. Exhibit 6 – Site Photographs is representative
of the photograph record collected on that day. The following is a description of the existing
conditions.

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
Aesthetics - The site is set in an urban area characterized by low profile structures and mature
vegetation. The site character blends well with the surrounding businesses and residences. The
existing façade of the recreation building reflects the style of the pioneer days of the City, and was
built in 1982 to emulate a historic structure that had been destroyed at an earlier date. The Conrad
Harrison Youth Center gym is the tallest and largest building on the block. The State of California
Youth Authority (CYA) funded it and the building was dedicated in 1994.
Agricultural Resources – Although El Centro houses agricultural processing facilities, the project
area is urban and does not contain any agricultural resources.
Air Quality – The project area is currently in State non-attainment status for the criteria pollutants
Ozone, particulate matter (PM). Air quality is primarily affected by vehicle, agricultural burning and
processing emissions that are trapped by an inversion layer in the atmosphere. An Air Quality
Attainment Plan is currently being implemented b7 the County’s Air Pollution Control District
(APCD) that contains both standard and discretionary minimization measures. There are no point
source emitters affecting the project.
Biological Resources – Due to the urban environment, there are no sensitive biological resources in
the project site or surroundings.
Cultural Resources – The site was reviewed by an MBA archaeologist who specializes in historic
architecture. Due to prior disturbances and modern developments onsite, there is very low potential
to find cultural resources. There are no known historic, prehistoric or paleontological resources
onsite.
Geology/Soils – Although no soil borings have been done on the project site, the entire City rests on a
bed of deep lacustrine (lakebed) deposits. Although the soil is suitable for agriculture, it presents
challenges for engineers on construction projects. The soils of this type typically need conditioning
to support structural footings including reinforced foundations with steel to prevent warping and
buckling.
Hazards/Hazardous Materials – The prior land use as a community swimming pool included pool
chemical storage, regulated by Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA). However,
no known chemical spills have occurred onsite.
Hydrology and Water Quality – Currently the site drains to the east of the premises. The site drains
into storm drains off site.
Land Use – The aquatic facility portion of the existing complex is not in service. However, the
Conrad Harrison Youth Center gymnasium continues to operate under normal business hours.

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
Mineral Resources – There are no known mineral resources onsite, and extraction of minerals will be
inappropriate at the location.
Noise – Land uses in the project area are primarily commercial, which is not considered noise
sensitive; however, there is a residential neighborhood to the south. The greatest source of noise in
the vicinity is attributed to traffic along Adams Avenue and 8
th
Street.
Population/Housing – Multiple family housing exists in the project area. The project site is located
in the downtown region with a population density greater than average for the City as a whole.
Public Services – El Centro provides a full compliment of public services to the project area, which
currently provides services to the Conrad Harrison Youth Center.
Recreation – The project site is currently in stages of dilapidation with the closure of the site’s
aquatic swimming pool, and with only the Youth Center remaining operational to the public.
Traffic – Current access to the project site is entered from off of Park Avenue (a 2-lane collector)
between North 7
th
Street North 8
Th
Street. The project site also abuts Adams Avenue to the north,
which is a 4-lane Divided Arterial.
Utilities/Service Systems – A full compliment of utilities are available onsite.
NORT
H
Michael Brandman Associates

text.b: M E X I C O

Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
a) Have a substantial adverse effect on a scenic
vista?
b) Substantially damage scenic resources,
including, but not limited to, trees, rock
outcroppings, and historic building within a
state scenic highway?
c) Substantially degrade the existing visual
character or quality of the site and its
surroundings?
d) Create a new source of substantial light or glare
which would adversely affect day or nighttime
views in the area?

text.i: In determining whether impacts to agricultural resources are significant environmental effects, lead
agencies may refer to the California Agricultural Land Evaluation and Site Assessment Model (1997)
prepared by the California Department of Conservation as an optional model to use in assessing

page.text: a) Convert Prime Farmland, Unique Farmland, or
Farmland of Statewide Importance (Farmland),
as shown on the maps prepared pursuant to the
Farmland Mapping and Monitoring Program
(FMMP) of the California Resources Agency, to
non-agricultural use?
b) Conflict with existing zoning for agricultural
use, or a Williamson Act contract?
c) Involve other changes in the existing
environment which, due to their location or
nature, could result in conversion of Farmland,
to non-agricultural use?

text.i: Where available, the significance criteria established by the applicable air quality management or air
pollution control district may be relied upon to make the following determinations.

page.text: a) Conflict with or obstruct implementation of the
applicable air quality plan?
b) Violate any air quality standard or contribute
substantially to an existing or projected air
quality violation?

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
c) Result in a cumulatively considerable net
increase of any criteria pollutant for which the
project region is non-attainment under an
applicable federal or state ambient air quality
standard (including releasing emissions, which
exceed quantitative thresholds for ozone
precursors)?
d) Expose sensitive receptors to substantial
pollutant concentrations?
e) Create objectionable odors affecting a
substantial number of people?
f)
Result in an increase in greenhouse gas
emissions that would significantly hinder or
delay the State's ability to meet the reduction
targets contained in AB 32?
a) Have a substantial adverse effect, either directly
or through habitat modifications, on any species
identified as a candidate, sensitive, or special
status species in local or regional plans, policies,
or regulations, or by the California Department
of Fish and Game (CDFG) or U.S. Fish and
Wildlife Service (USFWS)?
b) Have a substantial adverse effect on any riparian
habitat or other sensitive natural community
identified in local or regional plans, policies,
and regulations or by the CDFG or USFWS?
c) Have a substantial adverse effect on federally
protected wetlands as defined by Section 404 of
the Clean Water Act (including, but not limited
to, marsh, vernal pool, coastal, etc.) through
direct removal, filling, hydrological
interruption, or other means?
d) Interfere substantially with the movement of any
native resident or migratory fish or wildlife
species or with established native resident or
migratory wildlife corridors, or impede the use
of wildlife nursery sites?
e) Conflict with any local policies or ordinances
protecting biological resources, such as a tree
preservation policy or ordinance?

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
f)
Conflict with the provisions of an adopted
Habitat Conservation Plan (HCP), Natural
Community Conservation Plan, or other
approved local, regional, or state habitat
conservation plan?
a) Cause a substantial adverse change in the
significance of a historical resource as defined
b) Cause a substantial adverse change in the
significance of an archaeological resource
pursuant to §15064.5?
c) Directly or indirectly destroy a unique
paleontological resource or site or unique
geologic feature?
d) Disturb any human remains, including those
interred outside of formal cemeteries?
a) Expose people or structures to potential
substantial adverse effects, including the risk of
loss, injury or death involving:
i)
Rupture of a known earthquake fault, as
delineated on the most recent Alquist-
Priolo Earthquake Fault Zoning Map
issued by the State Geologist for the area
or based on other substantial evidence of a
known fault? Refer to Division of Mines
and Geology Special Publication 42.
ii)
Strong seismic ground shaking?
iii)
Seismic-related ground failure, including
liquefaction?
iv)
Landslides?
b) Result in substantial soil erosion or the loss of
topsoil?
c) Be located on a geologic unit or soil that is
unstable, or that would become unstable as a
result of the project and potentially result in on-
or off-site landslide, lateral spreading,
subsidence, liquefaction or collapse?
d) Be located on expansive soil, as defined in
Table 18-1-B of the Uniform Building Code
(1994), creating substantial risks to life or

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
property?
e) Have soils incapable of adequately supporting
the use of septic tanks or alternative wastewater
disposal systems where sewers are not available
for the disposal of wastewater?
a) Create a significant hazard to the public or the
environment through the routine transport, use,
or disposal of hazardous materials?
b) Create a significant hazard to the public or the
environment through reasonably foreseeable
upset and accident conditions involving the
likely release of hazardous materials into the
environment?
c) Emit hazardous emissions or handle hazardous
or acutely hazardous materials, substances, or
waste within one-quarter mile of an existing or
proposed school?
d) Be located on a site which is included on a list
of hazardous materials sites compiled pursuant
to Government Code Section 65962.5 and, as a
result, would it create a significant hazard to the
public or the environment?
e) For a project located within an airport land use
plan or, where such a plan has not been adopted,
within two miles of a public airport or public
use airport, would the project result in a safety
hazard for people residing or working the
project area?
f)
For a project within the vicinity of a private
airstrip, would the project result in a safety
hazard for people residing or working in the
project area?
g) Impair implementation of or physically interfere
with an adopted emergency response plan or
emergency evacuation plan?
h) Expose people or structures to a significant risk
of loss, injury or death involving wildland fires,
including where wildlands are adjacent to
urbanized areas or where residences are
intermixed with wildlands?
a) Violate any water quality standards or waste
discharge requirements?

i.b: City of El Centro – Adams Avenue Indoor Sports Complex
Initial Study and Mitigated Negative Declaration

page.text: H:\Client\2799-City of El Centro\2799.0026 Initial Study 4-16-09.doc
b) Substantially deplete groundwater supplies or
interfere substantially with groundwater
recharge such that there would be a net deficit in
aquifer volume or a lowering of the local
groundwater table level (e.g., the production
rate of pre-existing nearby wells would drop to a
level which would not support existing land
uses or planned uses for which permits have
been granted?
c) Substantially alter the existing drainage pattern
of area, including through the alteration of the
course of a stream or river, in a manner, which
would result in substantial erosion or siltation
on- or off-site?
d) Substantially alter the existing drainage pattern
of the site or area, including through the
alteration of the course of a stream or river, or
substantially increase the rate or amount of
surface runoff in a manner, which would result
in flooding on- or off-site?
e) Create or contribute runoff water, which would
exceed the capacity of existing or planned
stormwater drainage systems or provide
substantial additional sources of polluted
runoff?
f)
Otherwise substantially degrade water quality?
g) Place housing within a 100-year flood hazard
area as mapped on a federal Flood Hazard
Boundary or Flood Insurance Rate Map or other
flood hazard delineation map?
h) Place within a 100-year flood hazard area
structures, which would impede or redirect
flood flows?
i)
Expose people or structures to a significant risk
of loss, injury or death involving flooding,
including flooding as a result of the failure of a
levee or dam?
j)
Inundation by seiche, tsunami, or mudflow?
a) Physically divide an established community?
b) Conflict with any applicable land use plan,
policy, or regulation of an agency with
jurisdiction over the project (including, but not
limited to the general plan, specific plan, local
coastal program, or zoning ordinance) adopted
